title: For E0401, mention item definition being the problem

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code: <!-- Please provide a link to play.rust-lang.org -->

```rust
fn foo<T>() {
    const SIZE: usize = core::mem::size_of::<T>();
}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0401]: can't use generic parameters from outer function
 --> src/lib.rs:2:46
  |
1 | fn foo<T>() {
  |        - type parameter from outer function
2 |     const SIZE: usize = core::mem::size_of::<T>();
  |                                              ^ use of generic parameter from outer function
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
Ideally the output should look like:

```
error[E0401]: item definitions can't use generic parameters from outer function
 --> src/lib.rs:2:46
  |
1 | fn foo<T>() {
  |        - type parameter from outer function
2 |     const SIZE: usize = core::mem::size_of::<T>();
  |                                              ^ use of generic parameter from outer function
  = help: items can't use generic parameters from outer scope, where items are:
  = help: statics, consts, type definitions, etc. // should this list be included?
```

<!--
If the problem is not self-explanatory, please provide a rationale for the
change.
-->

I didn't fully understood why there are places you can't use generic parameters inside a function. When someone mentioned that the issue is that items act as if they are defined outside (with only their name being scoped), I understood (I think) that these "places" are exactly item definitions.
